{{Infobox video game | title = Pilgrim: Faith as a Weapon | image = File:Pilgrim, Faith as a Weapon cover.jpeg | developer = [[Arxel Tribe]] | publisher = [[Infogrames|Infogrames Multimedia]] | platforms = [[Microsoft Windows]] | released = November 1997 | genre = [[Adventure game|Adventure]], [[Educational game|educational]] | designer = Nicolas Fructus, Moebius | writer = Paulo Coelho | composer = Jacques Nelissen, Kristjan Cocev }} '''''Pilgrim: Faith as a Weapon''''' is a 1997 adventure video game, written by [[Paulo Coelho]], who wrote ''[[The Pilgrimage]]'', the novel on which the game is based. ''Pilgrim'' has been described as a "commercial cultural heritage game"<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.allianceexperts.com/en/knowledge/main-trends-serious-gaming-industry/|title=Main trends in the serious gaming industry|last=de Leede|first=Judith|date=|publisher=Alliance Experts|access-date=2017-01-28}}</ref> and "graphic interactive fiction".<ref name=":110">{{Cite web|url=http://www.justadventure.com/reviews/Pilgrim/Pilgrim_review.shtm |title=Review: Pilgrim |last=Ivey |first=Ray |date=July 20, 2001 |publisher=Just Adventure |access-date=2017-01-28 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20010720051207/http://www.justadventure.com/reviews/Pilgrim/Pilgrim_review.shtm |archivedate=July 20, 2001 |df= }}</ref> It is the premiere title of [[Arxel Tribe]]<ref name=":102">{{Cite web|url=http://www.digiworldsummit2014.com/intervenant/guillaume-de-fondaumiere/|title=Guillaume DE FONDAUMIERE|last=|first=|date=November 20, 2014|publisher=DigiWorld Summit|access-date=}}{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> and the first in The Paulo Coelho trilogy, alongside ''[[The Legend of the Prophet and the Assassin]]'' (1999) and ''[[The Secrets of Alamut]]'' (2001).
==Plot== [[File:Pilgrim, Faith as a Weapon_Petrus.jpg|left|thumb|368x368px|The second half of the game sees a tonal shift from the first; upon meeting the character of Petrus (<nowiki>''</nowiki>pictured<nowiki>''</nowiki>), ''Pilgrim'' goes beyond a series of fetch-quests and becomes infused with the philosophies of Coelho's source material novel encompassing a larger spiritual narrative.]] The game is loosely based on [[Paulo Coelho]]'s autobiographical 1987 novel ''[[The Pilgrimage]]''. It is a time of superstition and religious persecution,<ref name=":02">{{Cite web|url=https://translate.google.com.au/translate?sl=auto&tl=en&js=y&prev=_t&hl=en&ie=UTF-8&u=https://web.archive.org/web/20091211202250/http://www.puntaeclicca.it/rec/pilgrim.html&edit-text=&act=url|title=Pilgrim (''Italian'')|last=Gioconda|first=Aspide|date=|website=Puntaeclicca|publisher=|access-date=2017-01-28}}</ref> where [[Catharism]] reigns supreme. Set at the beginning of the [[Albigensian Crusade]] (1208) in the south of France, the story sees Simon Lancroix aim to complete his dying father's wishes of finding a secret manuscript and delivering it to a friend named Petrus. It is revealed that this actually a [[Coptic language|Coptic]] [[manuscript]] that a renegade [[Knights Templar|Templar]] brought back from [[Crusades]]; it is believed to be the lost [[Gospel of Saint Jean]]. This manuscript gets passed around to various characters and locations. Meanwhile, [[Pope Innocent III]] orders the inquisitor [[Diego de Osma]] to retrieve the manuscript. Mystical creatures such as angels and demons also become entangled in the battle.<ref name=":42">{{Cite web|url=http://quedzasvideogames.free.fr/?page=pilgrim/pilgrim.php|title=Pilgrim (''French'')|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=Quedzas Video Games|access-date=2017-01-28}}</ref>
The first half of the game sees the player complete a series of tasks to help other characters, who in return help the player. Halfway through the game, the player meets Petrus, who reveals that the player's father was the leader of a fictional religious sect called "The Tradition", which aims to bring an absolute truth that no other religion can.<ref name=":122">{{Cite web|url=http://www.hardcoregaming101.net/pilgrim/pilgrim.htm|title=Pigrim: Faith as a Weapon|last=Poussier|first=Damien|date=July 12, 2012|publisher=Hardcore Gaming 101|access-date=2017-01-29}}</ref> From this point the game covers symbolic, spiritual, and supernatural philosophies such as dreams, peace, compassion, love, salvation, the four horsemen of the apocalypse, growing up and giving up, and re-learning what we knew as children; the final scene takes place in limbo.<ref name=":122" />
==Gameplay== ''Pilgrim'' is a first person point-and-click adventure. Players click through a series of static frames—a slideshow of pre-rendered 3D environments—to move around; one is not free of their movements and must often strategically click screen points in a certain order to reach a destination.<ref name=":122" /><ref name=":62">{{Cite web|url=https://translate.google.com.au/translate?hl=en&sl=fr&u=http://www.abandonware-france.org/ltf_abandon/ltf_jeu.php?id=1238&prev=search|title=Pilgrim: Par le Livre et par l'Epée (French)|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=Abandonware France|access-date=2017-01-29}}</ref> The cursor becomes an arrow to indicate a possible movement, and a click transitions the player to the next location.<ref name=":62" /> It is possible to die in the game; causes of death include the player failing to accomplish certain time-dependent challenges.<ref name=":122" /> If the player dies they are returned to the beginning of the latest checkpoint, often after a cutscene.<ref name=":42" /><ref name=":122" /> There are also two unwinnable states; one of them occurs if the player gives all their money to a beggar in Toulouse, despite them needing the money to go past the very next door.<ref name=":122" /> The player is encouraged to "save early, save often".<ref name=":122" /> The final puzzle of the game has been described as "no less than an exam about what you're supposed to have learned".<ref name=":122" /> The game comes with two discs, which are both required for game installation; regardless of where the player is, Disc 1 must be inserted every time the player boots up the game.
The "Inventory" interface contains three elements. "Bag" contains the acquired items<ref name=":42" /> (the player is limited in the number of items and the weight they can carry).<ref name=":62" /> "People" contains the characters that the player had encountered, knows about, or wants information on.<ref name=":42" /> "Items" contains the objects which have been seen or heard about but not acquired.<ref name=":42" /> "People" and "Items" of interest can be brought up as conversation topics with others.<ref name=":42" /> To use an item in "Bag", the player clicks on it to activate it (it then has a yellow box around it), then clicks "View".<ref name=":62" /> To offer a topic of discussion, the player clicks on an item in the "People" or "Items" tabs to activate it, then clicks on a character in the "View" screen to talk about it.<ref name=":62" /> The puzzles require both reflection and patience.<ref name=":42" /> The "Bag" items and the clues within the "Encyclopedia" can be applied and manipulated to solve puzzles thereby advancing the story.<ref name=":42" /> The latter is similar to how the Chronopedia in used in Broderbund adventure game ''[[Carmen Sandiego's Great Chase Through Time]]''.<ref name="learningvillage12">{{cite web|url=http://www.learningvillage.com/html/rcstime.html|title=Carmen Sandiego's Great Chase Through Time|publisher=Learning Village|accessdate=October 27, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130927155415/http://www.learningvillage.com/html/rcstime.html|archivedate=September 27, 2013|df=}}</ref> The game has a hint system to provide clues for the more obscure puzzles.<ref name=":42" /> The entries of the in-game "Encyclopedia" have been described as "spartan" due to consisting exclusively of text.<ref name=":122" /> Sometimes when a character mentions a topic that is available in the encyclopedia during a conversation, a keyword will appear on the screen which may then be clicked to bring up the corresponding entry.<ref name=":122" /> While not required, this feature allows the player to delve deeper into the interesting historical nuggets that feature throughout the game.<ref name=":122" /> The player has an in-game notebook, into which they may copy-paste extracts from the encyclopedia.<ref name=":122" />
==Development== {{multiple image <!-- Essential parameters --> | align = right | direction = vertical | width = | image1 = Paulo Coelho nrkbeta.jpg | width1 = 250 | caption1 = | image2 = Moebius Lodz 2008.jpg | width2 = 200 | caption2 = | footer = ''Pilgrim'' was based on a novel by Paulo Coelho (''above''), who served as the game's screenwriter. Moebius (''below'') came onto the project as lead designer. }}
===Inspiration=== [[Arxel Tribe]] was founded in 1990 by two Slovenian architects named Matjaž Požlep and Diego Zanco.<ref name=":122" /><ref name=":4" /> Prior to ''Pilgrim'', the company had been known for designing and producing animated computer graphics for the architecture industry on Silicon Graphics computers from three agencies in Ljubljana, Paris and Milan.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://translate.google.com.au/translate?hl=en&sl=sl&tl=en&u=https://web.archive.org/web/19970626011637/http://www.arxel.si:80/tribe/arxel02mm.htm&sandbox=1|title=Article about Arxel Tribe (''Slovenian'')|last=|first=|date=June 1997|website=|publisher=Media and Marketing Magazine|access-date=2017-01-28}}</ref><ref name=":7">{{Cite web|url=http://www.game-exe.ru/exenews/8032/for_print.html |title=The Legend of the Prophet and the Assassin (''Russian'') |last= |first= |date=March 22, 2001 |website=Game.EXE |publisher= |access-date=2017-02-01 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140821232030/http://www.game-exe.ru/exenews/8032/for_print.html |archivedate=August 21, 2014 |df= }}</ref> Frenchmen Stephen Carrière and Guillaume de Fondaumière joined the company three years later in 1993.<ref name=":122" /> They helped diversify it into a special effects company for the advertising industry in 1994 by creating an educational film for an Italian design agency, which went on to win awards and be featured at the Berlin Film Festival.<ref name=":7" /> That experience gave the team a desire to create graphics as a means of expression, and to pursue more ambitious projects in the entertainment industry; specifically for video games.<ref name=":7" /> Arxel Tribe tried to raise funds for over a year to pursue the goal, but were unsuccessful at the time.<ref name=":7" /> In 1996, Anne Carriére Multimédia was founded as a subsidiary arm of Anne Carriére, the publishing house in charge of the French publication of work by Brazilian novelist [[Paulo Coelho]]<ref name=":112">{{Cite web|url=https://translate.google.com.au/translate?hl=en&sl=pt&u=http://www1.folha.uol.com.br/fsp/informat/fr170928.htm&prev=search|title="Diário de Um Mago" vira game (''Brazilian Portuguese'')|last=Zilveti|first=Marijô|date=September 17, 1997|website=|publisher=Folha De S.Paulo|access-date=}}</ref> and French cartoon artist [[Jean Giraud]] (also known as Mœbius).<ref name=":122" /> The subsidiary was created to specialise in the production of a genre of video games called "author games"; they chose Arxel Tribe to serve as the development team for the title.<ref name=":32">{{Cite web|url=http://www.arxel.si/tribe/text02.htm |title=Work In Progress |last= |first= |date=1997 |publisher=Arxel Tribe |access-date=2017-01-28 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/19970626010129/http://www.arxel.si/tribe/text02.htm |archivedate=1997-06-26 |df= }}</ref><ref name=":52">{{Cite web|url=http://www.arxel.si/tribe/arxel031pil.htm |title=Pilgrim |last= |first= |date= |publisher=Arxel Tribe |access-date=2017-01-28 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/19970626011615/http://www.arxel.si/tribe/arxel031pil.htm |archivedate=1997-06-26 |df= }}</ref> Stephen Carrière's mother, Anne, was the head of [[Anne Carriére]] publishing house; this well-connectedness allowed for the ability for Arxel Tribe to collaborate with a high calibre of creative talent on its debut foray into the video game space<ref name=":122" /><ref name=":22">{{Cite web|url=https://translate.google.com.au/translate?hl=en&sl=auto&tl=en&u=https://web.archive.org/web/19970626011629/http://www.arxel.si:80/tribe/arxel02stop.htm|title=Article about Arxel Tribe: NA ROMARSKI POTI (''Slovenian'')|last=|first=|date=June 1997|website=|publisher=Stop magazine|access-date=2017-01-28}}</ref><ref name=":6" />
The premiere project of the new venture was chosen by Anne Carriére Multimédia to be an adventure game based off [[Paulo Coelho|Coelho]]'s ''[[The Pilgrimage]]'' (1987) while the artistic direction was handed to French comic artist and frequent video game collaborator [[Jean Giraud]] (aka Moebius); ''The Pilgrimage'' would be his last gaming project.<ref name=":32" /><ref name=":52" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.kotaku.com.au/2012/03/remembering-moebius-a-man-who-helped-video-games-more-than-you-might-think/|title=Remembering Moebius, A Man Who Helped Video Games More Than You Might Think|last=Plunkett|first=Luke|date=March 12, 2012|work=Kotaku|access-date=2017-01-28|via=}}</ref><ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=https://translate.google.com.au/translate?hl=en&sl=fr&u=http://bounthavy.com/wordpress/moebius-game/&prev=search|title=Moebius et le jeu vidéo : game over (''French'')|last=BOUNTHAVY|first=|date=May 5, 2014|website=|publisher=Difficile d'écrire sur des futilités|access-date=2017-01-31}}</ref> Moebius had previously contributed art illustrations to the French edition of one of Coelho's books,<ref name=":122" /> and had designed covers for gaming projects such as ''[[Panzer Dragoon]]'' (1995) and ''[[Fade to Black (video game)|Fade to Black]]'' (1995).<ref name=":3" /> Coelho's books had sold in the millions, and this provided an incentive for the threads of his work to be woven into giant PC games.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://translate.google.com.au/translate?hl=en&sl=de&tl=en&u=http://www.pcgames.de/?article_id=11627|title=Render-Adventure im Stil von Myst (''German'')|last=|first=|date=September 27, 2001|website=|publisher=PC Games|access-date=2017-01-30}}</ref> According to SK Online, Coelho "accepted the proposal with great pleasure" after learning that the general appearance of the game would be decided by Moebius.<ref name=":182">{{Cite web|url=https://translate.googleusercontent.com/translate_c?depth=1&hl=en&prev=search&rurl=translate.google.com.au&sl=sr&sp=nmt4&u=http://www.sk.rs/2001/03/siop06.html&usg=ALkJrhj5cponAYNkYiuprWUKyauafGJQ_A|title=The Legend of the Prophet & the Assassin (''Serbian'')|last=MACEDONIĆ|first=Slobodan|date=March 2001|website=|publisher=SK Online|access-date=2017-01-30}}</ref> Moebius and [[Paulo Coelho|Coelho]] started the design work in 1996.<ref name=":72">{{Cite web|url=http://www.arxeltribe.com/corporate/ |title=About The Tribe |last= |first= |date=August 2, 2002 |publisher=Arxel Tribe |access-date=2017-01-29 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20020802233214/http://www.arxeltribe.com/corporate/ |archivedate=August 2, 2002 |df= }}</ref><ref name=":82">{{Cite web|url=http://www.arxeltribe.com/pilgrim/ |title=Pilgrim information |last= |first= |date=August 2, 2002 |website= |publisher=Arxel Tribe |access-date=2017-01-29 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20020802233237/http://www.arxeltribe.com/pilgrim/ |archivedate=August 2, 2002 |df= }}</ref> In 1996, one short year since their last diversification, Arxel Tribe had a meeting with Coelho and Moebius, with the result being the company switching gears to become a video game development studio and signing onto the project, which was to be published by Infogrames in 1997.<ref name="Google Translate2">{{Cite web|url=https://translate.google.com.au/translate?hl=en&sl=fr&u=http://www.idate.org/jii05/speakers/defondaumiere.php&prev=search|title=4th INTERNATIONAL VIDEO GAME FORUM: Guillaume DE FONDAUMIERE (''French'')|last=|first=|date=November 22, 2005|publisher=Content Industries & Broadband Economies|access-date=2017-01-29}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.thefreelibrary.com/MILIA+GAMES+'99:+Getting+Ahead+of+the+Game.-a053332231|title=MILIA GAMES '99: Getting Ahead of the Game|last=|first=|date=December 2, 1998|publisher=Business Wire|access-date=2017-01-29}}</ref> Fondaumière recalled "sitting at a bar in Frankfurt with Paulo Coelho [and] discussing the crazy idea of creating a videogame together".<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.gamesindustry.biz/articles/2010-09-29-15-years-of-playstation-article?page=1|title=Celebrating 15 Years of PlayStation|last=Martin|first=Matt|date=September 29, 2010|work=|newspaper=GamesIndustry.biz|language=en|access-date=2017-02-01|via=}}</ref> Stephen Carrière and Guillaume de Fondaumière helped Arxel Tribe re-position itself as a developer of "author games",<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.game-connection.com/conference?page=speakers&type=all|title=Guillaume de Fondaumière|last=|first=|date=|website=Game Connection|publisher=|access-date=2017-01-29}}</ref> and the company bought the rights to publishing a video game adaption of ''Pilgrim''.<ref name=":7" /> Arxel Tribe had made a lot of money in the advertising industry and had grown a desire to move into the video gaming industry; they were currently in a financially agreeable state to pursue this vision.<ref name=":142">{{Cite web|url=https://translate.google.com.au/translate?hl=en&sl=de&u=http://www.gameswelt.at/heavy-rain/special/film-noir-in-der-lederergasse,6281,3&prev=search|title=Interview Guillaume de Fondaumière, Co-CEO von Quantic Dream und Produzent von Heavy Rain (''German'')|last=Schneeweiss|first=Hans|date=February 23, 2010|website=|publisher=Gameswelt|access-date=2017-01-29}}</ref> Moebius required 20 million francs of investment to become involved.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com.au/books?id=L7BNAQAAIAAJ&q=%22pilgrim%22+%22arxel+tribe%22&dq=%22pilgrim%22+%22arxel+tribe%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjknuu7y-fRAhXKkpQKHVJhBKcQ6AEIXjAJ|title=Paris Match (French)|last=|first=|date=1998-12-01|publisher=|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=|quote=|via=}}</ref> Matja Požlep noted that creating a game based on Coelho's work was useful because potential customers would have already had an acquaintance with his work.<ref name=":5">{{Cite news|url=|title=Osnovna vrednota so mediloveški odnosi (''Slovenian'')|last=Fridi|first=Malda|date=June 10, 1999|work=Tednik|issue=23|page=5|access-date=|via=}}</ref> Guillaume de Fondaumiere recalled that as professionals, Coelho and Mobius charged a high price for their effort, and had a highly ambitious, challenging, and expensive vision; Arxel Tribe's lack of experience in video game development meant that the collaboration became "fantastic, but also a painful experience" much to their dismay.<ref name=":7" /> The game would originally be called ''Pilgrim'' during the development stage, and by its release would subtitled with ''Faith as a Weapon.''<ref name=":32" /><ref name=":52" />
Adventure gaming was chosen by Arxel Tribe because the genre had recently been experiencing technological advancements that were comparable to those seen in the shooting genre with new releases such as ''[[Doom (1993 video game)|Doom]]'' (1993) and ''[[Quake (video game)|Quake]]'' (1996), which opened up new graphical and narrative possibilities.<ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url=https://translate.google.com.au/translate?hl=en&sl=sl&u=http://www.delo.si/druzba/delova-borza-dela/z-racunalniskimi-igrami-na-svetovni-trg.html&prev=search|title=Z računalniškimi igrami na svetovni trg (''Slovenian'')|last=Ivanc|first=Staš|date=November 8, 2011|website=|publisher=Delo|access-date=2017-01-31}}</ref> Arxel Tribe aimed to create an adventure game with an "epic" and "gripping" narrative to give justice to the source material's "initiatory, romantic and spiritual journey".<ref name=":32" /><ref name=":52" /> They wanted to make a "humanist journey with a very deep story line", instead of being "just another adventure game".<ref name=":82" /> The development company collaborated with Coelho into adapting the story into more of an investigative detective mystery in order to better immerse the player while encouraging them to utilise their logic and imagination.<ref name=":32" /><ref name=":52" /> The early 13th century was chosen as the game's time period due to its "historical and mythical richness" abundant with heresy, crusades, and errands by knights; the developers felt this was the ideal setting to illustrate the "generous and humanist philosophy" inherent in Coelho's book.<ref name=":32" /><ref name=":52" /> Stephen Carrière expressed that video game manufacturers were drawn toward comic book writers, screenwriters or cartoonists due to their desire to create a unique graphic universe that sets the game apart from the rest of the market.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://translate.google.com.au/translate?hl=en&sl=fr&u=http://www.liberation.fr/ecrans/1999/05/07/des-bulles-dans-le-jeu-video-les-editeurs-de-jeux-sollicitent-de-plus-en-plus-les-auteurs-de-bande-d_272280&prev=search|title=Les éditeurs de jeux sollicitent de plus en plus les auteurs de bande dessinée dont ils prisent la créativité et les qualités de scénariste (''French'')|last=Riviore|first=Annick|date=May 7, 1999|website=|publisher=Liberation|access-date=2017-01-29}}</ref> Matjaz Požlep said the company worked within an adventure gaming niche, and within it an intellectual gaming sub-niche.<ref name=":4" /> Around this time 46 people were working on Arxel Tribe games at their Ljubljana company headquarters.<ref name=":5" />
===Design=== {{multiple image <!-- Essential parameters --> | align = left | direction = vertical | width = | image1 = Pilgrim, Faith as a Weapon concept art.jpeg | width1 = 250 | caption1 = | image2 = Pilgrim, Faith as a Weapon 3D models.jpeg | width2 = 250 | caption2 = | footer = Examples of the original concept art by Moebius (''above'') and the final 3D models featured in the game (''below''). }}While Guillaume de Fondaumière considered video gaming a mere extension of their 3D studio business, he was neither a programmer or graphic artist, so he assumed the role of producer and sought to find people who cared about the creative side of game development.<ref name=":142" /> With a team of "galley slaves", they managed to complete the game in a mere 15 months.<ref name=":7" />
Moebius collaborated with Arxel Tribe artistic director Nicolas Fructus on the game's design elements to draw the concept art for scenes and characters.<ref name=":112" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://translate.google.com.au/translate?hl=en&sl=fr&u=http://www.humano.com/profil/Nicolas%252BFructus&prev=search|title=Nicolas Fructus dessinateur, scénariste (''French'')|last=Fructus|first=Nicolas|date=|website=|publisher=Humano|access-date=2017-01-28}}</ref> The development company felt that the drawings by Moebius enhanced the magical quality of the story, and provided a sense of cultural and spiritual curiosity, transcending the generic conventions of the adventure game genre.<ref name=":32" /><ref name=":52" /> The 2D character design work was done in both Ljubljana and Paris, while the adaptation of the designs using 3D graphic software was completed in Ljubljana<ref name=":22" /> Computer artists created 3D images from Moebius' drawings using [[Silicon Graphics]] computers (such as Onyx and Indigo 2, which they had used in previous non-video game projects<ref name="auto2">{{Cite web|url=http://www.arxel.si/tribe/arxel0.htm |title=Arxel Tribe – History |last= |first= |date=1997 |publisher=Arxel Tribe |access-date=2017-01-28 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/19970626010109/http://www.arxel.si/tribe/arxel0.htm |archivedate=1997-06-26 |df= }}</ref>); they mixed traditional computer graphics techniques, such as rigging, with motion capture in order to animate the characters.<ref name=":32" /><ref name=":52" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.samohomsak.com/documents/SamoHomsak_resume.pdf|title=Samo Homsak|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref>
The game's 3D engine was created in-house ar Pilgrim, and the computer-rendered elements like scenes and characters weremade to look on par with the top level video game developers of the time.<ref name=":22" /> Marcin Mierzejewski Zenzire approached Arxel Tribe in 1996 to become a 3D modeller and animator, but was instead hired as a coder for this game. At the time the company had limited coding experience from their previous multimedia projects, so they needed a professional coder.<ref name=":92">{{Cite web|url=http://www.sinistersystems.com/dokuwiki/doku.php?id=charon:past:arxeltribe|title=Arxel Tribe (1996–2003)|last=Zenzire|first=Marcin Mierzejewski|date=November 18, 2011|publisher=Sinister Systems|access-date=2017-01-29}}</ref> Zenzire "set up the initial architecture for the game engine, coded some UI routines and the game's interactive encyclopedia", using expertise from his work using hypertext. He also "supervised the code and offered assistance with other programming tasks".<ref name=":92" />
Early in development, a complete literature research was carried out in order to provide the team with a comprehensive and faithful design guide containing each historical element the project required, such as clothes, architecture, and landscapes.<ref name=":32" /><ref name=":52" /> To give the player a colourful window into the complexities of the time period, a multimedia encyclopedia containing biographical information such as maps, articles, and paintings was included in-game; the over 150 page data bank is divided into three parts: "History & Geography", "Life in the Middle Ages" and "Religion".<ref name=":42" /><ref name=":32" /><ref name=":52" /> This 13th century information was added to provide additional historical knowledge and context.<ref name=":22" /> The game was created with the participation of [[National Center of Cinematography and the moving image|Le Centre National de la Cinématographie]] and the Ministèr Délégué à la Poste aux Télécommunications et à l'Espace.<ref name="auto12">{{Cite web|url=http://www.mobygames.com/game/windows/pilgrim-faith-as-a-weapon/credits|title=Pilgrim: Faith as a Weapon credits|last=|first=|date=|website=MobyGames|publisher=|access-date=2017-01-28}}</ref>
Most of the game's background music was not written for the game; it was instead chosen from preexisting music, largely from the Medieval and Romantic periods.<ref name=":6" /> This includes: [[Symphony No. 1 (Mahler)|Symphony No. 1 in D major]] by [[Gustav Mahler]], a piece by [[Fernando Sor]], a guitar-transcribed version of [[Isaac Albéniz]]'s piano pieces [[Suite Española No. 1, Op. 47]] and [[Cantos de españa|Cantos de España]], and [[Greensleeves]].<ref name=":42" /><ref name=":62" /> The pieces are relatively short and loop indefinitely in their respective locations.<ref name=":122" /> The game is in the SVGA 640x480 aspect ratio,<ref name=":62" /> and was made available into English, French, German and Brazilian Portuguese.<ref name=":82" />
===Release=== In June 1997, Arxel reported on their website that the game was likely to be completed that December, with a world release planned for the Spring of 1998.<ref name=":32" /><ref name=":52" /><ref name=":22" /> At the time, Parisian company Anne Carierre Multimedia was confirmed as co-producer of the game, while the major worldwide distribution companies were still being negotiated.<ref name=":32" /><ref name=":52" /><ref name=":22" /> Later that year, Infogrames Entertainment signed a first publishing and distribution contract with Arxel Tribe.<ref name=":72" /> The project was officially announced to the press during a candlelit dinner held in a castle in Ljubljana in September 1997, with an intended release date of November of that year.<ref name=":112" /> The small multimedia studio treated the journalists to a sample of local handicrafts at the beginning of the evening, and then invited them to a memorable conference in the castle hall.<ref name=":8">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com.au/books?id=e35A889hwQ4C&pg=PT218&dq=%22pilgrim%22+%22arxel+tribe%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi3od60uOfRAhWBFZQKHV_RDeoQ6AEISTAG#v=onepage&q=%22pilgrim%22%20%22arxel%20tribe%22&f=false|title=Relations Presse (French)|last=Ichbiah|first=Daniel|publisher=Daniel Ichbiah|year=|isbn=9781291317022|location=|pages=|quote=|via=}}</ref>
The game would be released in the US and Europe in November 1997 in English, French (''Pilgrim: Par le Livre et par l'Epée''), and German (''Pilgrim: Das Geheimnis der Schrift''), with a Brazilian Portuguese release entitled ''O Diário de um Mago'' being released in January 1998.<ref name=":112" /> The game ended up being published first in the UK in February 1998 by Infogrames Multimedia; the French publication was handled by [[Wanadoo Edition]] (formed by index+'s acquisition of France Télécom Multimédia), and the French trailer was created by Eurospace, advertised by Infogrames, and directed by Lioux Philippe.<ref name=":72" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://translate.google.com.au/translate?hl=en&sl=fr&tl=en&u=http://www.ina.fr/video/PUB777003059|title=Pilgrim (''French'')|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=Institut National de l'Audiovisuel|access-date=2017-02-01}}</ref> The game was also available for purchase via the Arxel Tribe webstore.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=http://www.gameboomers.com/MemberReviews/Pp/pilgrimbyclovis.htm |title=Pilgrim |last=Clovis |first= |date=December 8, 2003 |publisher=Gameboomers |access-date=2017-01-31 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20031208105211/http://www.gameboomers.com/MemberReviews/Pp/pilgrimbyclovis.htm |archivedate=December 8, 2003 |df= }}</ref> As a promotion, Arxel Tribe announced they would give a free copy of the game to the first 200 people to send the company their full details.<ref name="auto2" /> In total, $2 million was invested into the venture; of this, $1 million went toward the production of the title by Arxel Tribe and Anne Carrière Multimedia, while another $1 million was spent to promote the title which was distributed worldwide by French company Infogrames.<ref name=":112" /> 250,000 copies of the video game were published.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://fr.linkedin.com/in/gdefondaumiere |title=Guillaume de Fondaumière (''French'') |last= |first= |date=January 10, 2013 |work=LinkedIn |access-date=2017-01-29 |via= |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130110061724/http://fr.linkedin.com/in/gdefondaumiere |archivedate=January 10, 2013 |df= }}</ref>
Just Adventure described ''Pilgrim'' as a "little-known title", noting that by the time of its sequel's release in 1999, ''Pilgrim'' had still never released in North America.<ref name=":152">{{Cite web|url=http://www.justadventure.com/reviews/LOPA/LOPA.shtm |title=Review: The Legend of the Prophet and the Assassin |last=Sluganski |first=Randy |date=July 20, 2001 |website= |publisher=Just Adventure |access-date=2017-01-30 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20010720052507/http://www.justadventure.com/reviews/LOPA/LOPA.shtm |archivedate=July 20, 2001 |df= }}</ref> It noted that there were three potential culprits to the gaming "gem" suffering in terms of recognition: little to no marketing by Arxel Tribe, the publisher not understanding how to sell the product, and the gaming industry simply being apathetic toward adventure games at the time.<ref name=":152" /> Game coder Marcin Mierzejewski Zenzire would later argue that while the title was a decent success among adventure fans and created a reasonable amount of media buzz, Arxel Tribe used the boom in popularity to promote themselves rather than the game, which meant a "comparatively small number of copies was printed and therefore sold out almost immediately".<ref name=":92" /> SK Online wrote that the game was only a half-hearted success, partly because of the lack of advertising, but also because it had some technical deficiencies when compared to its contemporaries.<ref name=":182" /> Clovis of Gameboomers noted that during its rollout, there were "significant delays in delivery".<ref name=":2" /> ''Just Adventure'' reported that ''Pilgrim'' was originally supposed to be included as a bonus feature in the release of ''[[The Legend of the Prophet and the Assassin]]'', but that this idea was later abandoned, describing it as "yet another marketing mistake".<ref name=":162">{{Cite web|url=http://www.justadventure.com/articles/Nobody_Played/10_Best.shtm |title=The 10 Best Adventure Games That (Almost) No One Has Ever Played |last=Sluganski |first=Randy |date=July 20, 2001 |website= |publisher=Just Adventure |access-date=2017-01-30 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20010720064032/http://www.justadventure.com/articles/Nobody_Played/10_Best.shtm |archivedate=July 20, 2001 |df= }}</ref> The article, published between review of ''[[The Secrets of Alamut]]'' in July 2001, ''Just Adventure'' wrote that ''Pilgrim'' had experienced a "rejuvenation in sales" in the time since it had been listed it in ''The Ten Best The game would not be reprinted until three years after its original release; it was re-released in France in March 2001 and the US in November 2001 (by [[Selectsoft Publishing]]) as a Deluxe Edition, In 2001, Ray Ivey of ''[[Just Adventure]]'', a self-professed fan of the developer due to ''[[Ring (video game)|Ring]]'' (1999) and ''[[Seven Games of the Soul|Faust]]'' (1999), picked up ''Pilgrim'' "mostly out of academic interest" to examine Axel Tribe's debut work; he described the title as "lovely", "mysterious", "educational", "compelling", and a great entry in the adventure game genre.<ref name=":110" /> That same year the publication's Randy Sluganski ranked the game 7th in his list of ''The 10 Best Adventure Games That (Almost) No One Has Ever Played'', complimenting it for tackling foreign video game territory such as theology and superstition, and describing it as an "artistic tour-de-force" that addresses its themes with a sense of adventurousness, power, and scope.<ref name=":162" /> Gordon Aplin of ''Metzomagic'' and ''Quandary'' didn't buy the game on its original release as the box cover mislead him into thinking the game was action/adventure ala ''[[Knight's Chase]]''; upon playing the game in 2001 he deemed it a valiant first effort by Arxel but incomparable to the later titles like [[Ring (video game)|''Ring'']] and [[Seven Games of the Soul|''Faust'']],<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.metzomagic.com/showArticle.php?index=406|title=Pilgrim: Faith as a Weapon|last=Aplin|first=Gordon|date=July 2001|publisher=Metzomagic.com|access-date=2017-01-28}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.quandaryland.com/jsp/dispArticle.jsp?index=406 |title=Pilgrim: Faith as a Weapon |last=Aplin |first=Gordon |date=July 2001 |publisher=Quandary |access-date=2017-01-28 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040109233325/http://www.quandaryland.com/jsp/dispArticle.jsp?index=406 |archivedate=2004-01-09 |df= }}</ref> and in a 1999 [[Seven Games of the Soul|''Faust'']] review ''Metzomagic''<nowiki/>'s Steve Metzler would say the company had "improved tremendously" when compared to Pilgrim's "incomprehensible" puzzle design.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.metzomagic.com/showArticle.php?index=855|title=Seven Games of the Soul / Faust (Second Opinion)|last=Metzler|first=Steve|date=November 1999|publisher=Metzomagic|access-date=2017-01-31}}</ref> Upon the release of ''The Legend of the Prophet & the Assassin, SK Online'' gave Arxel Tribe the distinction of being the first company from the former Yugoslavia to have "seriously sailed the choppy waters of the market of computer entertainment", citing the company's decision to adapt Coelho's novel into a computer game as a sign of them pursuing original ideas from the very start.<ref name=":182" /> In a 2002 review ''Tap Repeatedly<nowiki/>''<nowiki/>'s Enigma described the game as "mind-blowing", "stunning", "outrageous", and "constantly interesti''ng".''<ref name=":172" />

''Puntaeclicca''<nowiki/>'s Aspide Gioconda liked the game from both a historical and puzzle design perspective, though thought the game's bugs slightly conditioned its quality level.<ref name=":02" /> ''Quedzas Video Games'' thought the game's music was beautiful and atmospheric, citing the tune playing at [[Basilique St-Sernin, Toulouse|Saint-Sernin]] as evoking a sense of mystery.<ref name=":42" /> Mr. Bill & Lela from ''Mr. Bill's Adventureland Review'' praised the game for mixing educational historical elements seamlessly into the intriguing story.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.mrbillsadventureland.com/reviews/o-p/pilgrimR/pilgrimR.htm|title=Pilgrim: Faith as a Weapon|last=Mr. Bill & Lela|first=|date=|publisher=Mr. Bill's Adventureland Review|access-date=2017-01-28}}</ref> ''Abandonware France'' thought the graphics were plasticy, yet detailed and impressive for the time; the site also thought the French voice acting was generally good.<ref name=":62" /> The book ''Le livre de sagesse: supports, médiations, usages'' noted that games like Pilgrim demonstrate how the player's actions allow them to write or rewrite history; the fate of the narrative is in their hands.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://translate.google.com.au/translate?hl=en&sl=fr&u=https://books.google.com.au/books?id=ZjAUdHnCypMC&pg=PA345&lpg=PA345&dq=%2522arxel+tribe%2522+%2522pilgrim%2522&source=bl&ots=mCvxTFYuci&sig=-3fi4c5G_hYGohK1OZ7ow8RdpJg&prev=search|title=Le livre de sagesse (''French'')|last=Brucker|first=Nicolas|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=2017-01-28}}</ref> ''Studies in Medievalism'' explained that Pilgrim is one of only a handful of adventure video games set in the medieval period, alongside entries like Cryo Interactive's Arthur's Knights; the book suggested that Pilgrim "tries so hard to be authentic".<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com.au/books?id=kCorAQAAIAAJ&q=%22pilgrim%22+%22arxel+tribe%22&dq=%22pilgrim%22+%22arxel+tribe%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi3od60uOfRAhWBFZQKHV_RDeoQ6AEIKzAB|title=Studies in Medievalism|date=2008-01-01|publisher=D.S. Brewer|language=en}}</ref> Camille Saint-Jacques of ''Arts contemporains, 1950–2000'' thought Moebius' contribution toward the game was an example of the interest graphic artists of the time (particularly young ones) were having toward the multimedia and video games industry, which offered a more magnetic pull than traditional neuvième art (comic books); it noted that the Slovenian designers did not "disdain to be interested" in collaborating with a comic book artist.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com.au/books?id=o85NAAAAYAAJ&q=%22pilgrim%22+%22arxel+tribe%22&dq=%22pilgrim%22+%22arxel+tribe%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi3od60uOfRAhWBFZQKHV_RDeoQ6AEIUTAH|title=Arts contemporains, 1950–2000 (French)|last=Saint-Jacques|first=Camille|date=2002-01-01|publisher=Autrement|year=|isbn=9782746702820|location=|pages=|quote=|via=}}</ref> On his review site ''Feibel'', German journalist Thomas Feibel accused the 3D characters of moving around like "living helium balloons", due to their movements lacking in detail and precision.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://translate.google.com.au/translate?hl=en&sl=de&u=http://feibel.3q.de/index.php?id=7&catId=7&prodId=2529&cHash=7fc3e2247c1616ec38dd7d9e6ff82709&prev=search|title=Pilgrim (''German'')|last=Feibel|first=Thomas|date=|website=|publisher=Feibel|access-date=2017-01-31}}</ref> ''Gameboomers'' reviewer Clovis noted that [[pixel hunting]] is required early on, and that puzzles toward the end were so obscure he was forced to use a walkthough.<ref name=":2" />
Damien Poussier of ''[[Hardcore Gaming 101]]'' asserted that ''Pilgrim'' is the resulting blend of the "relative seriousness" and "classic feel" of Arxel Tribe (which he compared with [[Cryo Interactive]]), the "great artwork" of Moebius, and the "ridiculous new age philosophy" and "low-grade proselytizing" of Coelho.<ref name=":122" /> Poussier also compared the gameplay to ''[[Myst]]'' and liked that the game didn't follow the book too closely, noting that a "stain" of the "author's influence" wasn't noticeable until the game's midpoint; he thought the scene with Petrus was "completely out of the blue" and "filled with absolute nonsense that even the stonest of all hippies would find laughable".<ref name=":122" /> The ''Hardcore Gaming 101'' reviewer also criticised the plasticy characters which did not resemble Moebius' work, having to wait for characters to complete an animation before answering each question, and the "excruciatingly awful" voice acting of many characters, particularly the incorrect French and Spanish accents.<ref name=":122" /> Poussier praised the atmospheric music, as well as the "well-handed" education despite lamenting that the encyclopedia would have been more paletable had its walls of text been sprinkled with some images.<ref name=":122" />
==Legacy== The game received the Golden CD-ROM award in France, and various other international awards.<ref name=":72" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.history-adventures.com/index.php?sprache=E&genre=adv&zeit=mittelalter&game=pilgrim&az=g|title=Pilgrim|last=Steingrad|first=Elena|date=|publisher=History Adventures|access-date=2017-01-28|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080511061739/http://www.history-adventures.com/index.php?sprache=E&genre=adv&zeit=mittelalter&game=pilgrim&az=g#|archive-date=2008-05-11|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> According to Arxel Tribe, the game's release saw the developer become recognized for its "author games", which had beautiful graphics and scenario depth.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.arxeltribe.com/corporate/ |title=Arxel Tribe: About The Tribe |last= |first= |date=April 12, 2004 |website= |publisher=Arxel Tribe |access-date=2017-01-28 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040412123847/http://www.arxeltribe.com/corporate/ |archivedate=April 12, 2004 |df= }}</ref> The game turned out to be Arxel Tribe's prelude; it was followed by the company's "international breakthrough" hit ''[[Ring (video game)|Ring]]'' (1998), based on an opera by [[Richard Wagner]], which would sell 600,000 copies.<ref name=":102" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.gamesindustry.biz/articles/gamehorizon-conference-2009-playstation-home-boss-peter-edward-and-quantic-dream-s-guillaume-de-fondaumi-re-and-jamil-moledina-to-speak-next-month-in-gateshead|title=GameHorizon Conference 2009|newspaper=GamesIndustry.biz|language=en|access-date=2017-01-28}}</ref> ''Ring''{{'}}s game engine was based on the one created for ''Pilgrim''; therefore the titles had a similar architecture and design.<ref name=":92" />
After the release of ''Pilgrim'', Paulo Coelho decided to use this collaboration and newfound interest in interactive entertainment as the inspiration behind a recurring plot point in his 1998 novel ''[[Veronika Decides to Die]]'', which was released the same year as ''Pilgrim'' sequel ''The Legend of the Prophet and the Assassin''. In ''Veronika Decides to Die,'' the suicidal Ljubljana-born heroine reads an article in the French magazine ''Homme'' about a computer game developed in Slovenia and written by Coelho''.''<ref name=":182" /><ref name=":192" /><ref name=":202">{{Cite web|url=http://wiztrit.com/excerpt/?e=20t|title=Excerpt from Veronika Decides to Die|website=wiztrit.com|language=en|access-date=2017-01-31}}</ref> There are many references to ''Pilgrim'' and Coelho's thoughts on the experience throughout the book; the following passage illustrates this:{{Quotation|text="''Having nothing more interesting to do, [Veronika] decided to read the whole article, and she learned that the said computer game had been made in Slovenia -that strange country that no one seemed quite able to place, except the people who lived there – because it was a cheap source of labor. A few months before, when the product was launched, the French manufacturer had given a party for journalists from all over the world in a castle in Vled.'' ''Veronika remembered reading something about the party; which had been quite an event in the city, not just because the castle had been redecorated in order to match as closely as possible the medieval atmosphere of the CD-ROM, but because of the controversy in the local press: Journalists from Germany, France, Britain, Italy and Spain had been invited, but not a single Slovene...''"|sign=Paulo Coelho|source=excerpt from his 1998 novel ''Veronika Decides to Die''<ref>http://wiztrit.com/excerpt/?e=20t</ref>}}After ''Pilgrim'', it was decided that the " fruitful collaboration" between Arxel Tribe and Coelho would continue; this resulted in the creation of two more games set in the Medieval Middle East, creating an adventure trilogy.<ref name=":182" /><ref name=":192" /> ''The Legend of the Prophet and the Assassin'', also known as ''The Prophet's Trail'', (and called ''The Legend of As-Sayf: The Prophet and the Assasin'' during the development stage<ref name=":7" />), is sometimes referred to as ''Pilgrim II''; it is however less a direct sequel and more an "entirely new story about the same era as seen from another perspective", which carries over into the third game ''[[The Secrets of Alamut]]''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.mrbillsadventureland.com/reviews/k-l/legendarxR/legprophR.htm|title=The Legend of the Prophet and the Assassin Review – Mr. Bill's Adventureland|website=www.mrbillsadventureland.com|access-date=2017-01-29}}</ref> Described by Guillaume de Fondaumiere as a "kind of continuation",<ref name=":7" /> the game takes place 50 years after the events witnessed in ''Pilgrim'', although the game explores many of the same themes.<ref name=":182" /> Just Adventure noted that when the sequel was released in North America, ''Pilgrim'' still had not been, so there was no point in marketing the game as ''Pilgrim II''.<ref name=":152" /> In some releases the two games are considered ''Part 1'' and ''Part 2'' of the ''Legend'' series, with the bundled release also known as ''The Legend of the Prophet and the Assassin''.<ref name=":152" /> Throughout The Paul Coelho trilogy, ''Pilgrim'' protagonist Simon de Lancroix evolves from a "young, sense-seeking" person to someone who has "matured to a prophet, although not loved by everyone", according to Adventure-Archiv.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.adventurearchiv.de/d/alamutreviewen.htm|title=The Secret of Alamut – The Legend of the Prophet and the Assassin Part 2 – Review english|last=slydos|website=www.adventurearchiv.de|access-date=2017-01-29|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111231102536/http://www.adventurearchiv.de/d/alamutreviewen.htm|archivedate=2011-12-31|df=}}</ref> However, Damien Poussier of ''Hardcore Gaming 101'' argues that while Simon de Lancroix is mentioned in the sequel, the name is not referring to the same character from ''Pilgrim''.<ref name=":122" /> The Lancroix of the sequels is a European prophet who wanted to construct an oasis of peace called Jébus.<ref name=":182" /> The three titles which would form a collection; (alongside ''[[The Legend of the Prophet and the Assassin]]'' (2000) and ''[[The Secrets of Alamut]]'' (2001), which continued the story, the three games would be collectively be known as The [[Paulo Coelho]] trilogy).<ref name=":32" /><ref name=":52" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://translate.google.com.au/translate?hl=en&sl=pl&u=http://www.gry-online.pl/S016.asp?ID=1701&prev=search|title=Secrets of Alamut (''Polish'')|last=|first=|date=|publisher=Gry|access-date=2017-01-29}}</ref>
Guillaume de Fondaumiere later said that while he was proud of the game, it was not particularly impressive by the standards of the time.<ref name=":7" /> Many of the crew for this game would work together on other projects. 20 and 14 members of the creative team collaborated on ''[[Seven Games of the Soul|Faust: Seven Games of the Soul]]'' (1999) and ''[[The Legend of the Prophet and the Assassin]]'' (2000 – also written by Coelho), respectively.<ref name="auto12" /> Arxel Tribe would develop fifteen games, which would mostly share a series of common aspects: educational adventure games, set in specific historic times, and inspired by real or mythological events.<ref name=":122" /> Arxel Tribe would eventually be renamed Art Rebel, and create the graphic production and modeling for French video game developer [[White Birds Productions]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://translate.google.com.au/translate?hl=en&sl=fr&u=http://www.atlantisamerzoneetcie.com/jeux-dossier-lochness-visite-whitebirds.php&prev=search|title=Visit to the studios of White Birds Productions From Lochness|last=|first=|date=|publisher=Atlantis Amerzone Et Cie|access-date=2017-01-28}}</ref>

'''Rajgruha''' ([[Marathi language|Marathi]]: राजगृह) is a memorial and home of [[B. R. Ambedkar]] in [[Hindu colony]] of [[Dadar]] in [[Mumbai]], [[Maharashtra]], [[India]]. It was named ''[[Rajgriha]]'' (now [[Rajgir]]) in the memory of the ancient Buddhist kingdom. This historic monument is a three-storeyed building, the ground floor of the house is a museum. The photographs and ashes of Babasaheb Ambedkar are open to visitors here. This place is holy site for Indians especially Ambedkarite Buddhists and Dalits. Ambedkar lived in 'Rajgruha' for nearly 15-20 years.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.timesnownews.com/india/article/five-must-visit-places-to-rediscover-the-life-of-dr-babasaheb-ambedkar-chaitya-bhoomi-chaityabhoomi/140984|title=Five must visit places to rediscover the life of Dr Babasaheb Ambedkar {{!}} India News|access-date=2018-11-28|language=en-GB}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.loksatta.com/mumbai-news/hawkers-encroachment-near-ambedkar-house-at-dadar-1148960/|title=बाबासाहेबांच्या ‘राजगृहा’च्या आसपास फेरीवाल्यांचा डेरा|date=2015-10-10|work=Loksatta|access-date=2018-11-28|language=mr-IN}}</ref>
Millions of people and his followers (especially ''Ambedkarite Buddhists and dalits'') have come here to showcase the mansions before the [[Chaitya Bhoomi]] in [[Shivaji Park]] on 6th December. It was a plan to make a national monument, but it was not possible due to some legal and technical issues. Ambedkar had collected more than 50,000 books at the Rajgaura. This was the largest personal library in the world at that time. In 2013, the house of the mansion became a heritage monument.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Mahamanav Dr. Bhimrao Ramji Ambedkar|last=Gaikwad|first=Dr. Dnyanraj Kashinath|publisher=Riya Publication|year=2016|isbn=|location=|pages=186|language=Marathi}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://m.divyamarathi.bhaskar.com/news/MAH-MUM-dr-5268154-NOR.html|title=डॉ. बाबासाहेब अांबेडकरांच्या ‘राजगृह’ने घेतला मोकळा श्वास|work=divyamarathi|access-date=2018-11-28|language=mr}}</ref>
==History== [[File:Rajagriha, Bombay, February 1934. (L to R) Yashwant, BR Ambedkar, Ramabai, Laxmibai, Mukundrao, and Tobby.jpg|thumb|upright=1.5|[[Babasaheb Ambedkar]] with his family members at Rajgruha, his residence in Hindu Colony, Dadar (Bombay). From left – Yashwant (Son), Babasaheb Ambedkar, Smt. [[Ramabai Ambedkar|Ramabai]] (Wife), Smt. Laxmibai (Wife of his elder brother, Balaram), Mukund (Nephew) and Dr. Ambedkar’s dog, Tobby. On February 1934]]
Babasaheb Ambedkar's early days went into a very poor state. After barrister, he started to practice law. And in the short run he became famous as a smart lawyer. And after 1930, their financial condition was improving. Ambedkar's office was near Damodar Hall in Parel. Since the number of people to meet him increased ambedkars house at paybadevi seemed small to accommodate such that it couldn't even accommodate his books. So he decided to build a new house for themselves. When Ambedkar was standing his own building, he had prepared a plan for himself to have a library. He tried his best to have the characteristics of the best libraries he had seen abroad. In that structure, two blocks of three to three rooms were built on the ground floor of the Rajagruha. In those two blocks, he had arranged for his family's living arrangements. On the first floor of the royal house, Babasaheb had arranged his own personal library and office along with his own convenience. He had prepared his own plan and arranged it accordingly.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Mahamanav Dr. Bhimrao Ramji Ambedkar|last=Gaikwad|first=Dr. Dnyanraj Kashinath|publisher=Riya Publication|year=2016|isbn=|location=|pages=186|language=Marathi}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.thehindu.com/news/cities/mumbai/the-house-ambedkar-built-in-mumbai-gets-scant-notice/article7626379.ece|title=The house Ambedkar built in Mumbai gets scant notice|last=Rashid|first=Omar|date=2015-09-08|work=The Hindu|access-date=2018-11-28|language=en-IN|issn=0971-751X}}</ref>
In 1930, he owned 99th and 129th numbered two plots of each of 55 square yard area in the [[Hindu colony]] of Dadar, Mumbai. On the plot of 129th Street in the fifth lane, decided to build a house to live with his family, while building a rented building on the 99th plot in the third lane. He got loan from Central Bank of India for construction and started construction immediately. The work of supervising the construction of Mr. Aaiskar has been appointed. In January of 1931, the construction of the building on the 129th plot was started. It was completed in 1933 and construction of the house of 'Rajgruha' was built. Construction of another building on plot number 99 started in 1932. After completion of the construction, they named the building as "Char Minar". The name 'Rajgruha' was related to [[Buddhist culture]] and [[Hindu culture]], whereas the name 'Char Minar' was related to [[Muslim culture]]. Construction of the building completed in 1933. In 1933, Babasaheb Ambedkar, along with his family, had come to live in his Rajgruha. B. R. Ambedkar, his wife [[Ramabai Bhimrao Ambedkar|Ramabai]] (son), Yashwant, Laxmibai (wife of his brother), Mukund (nephew) etc. lived in the Rajgruha. Ambedkar had more than 50,000 books in the Rajgruha, that time Rajgruha was the largest personal library in the world. Later on 9 May 1941, he sold the "Char Minar" building to pay for the purchase of books and loan of other things. However, they kept the house of Rajgruha for a permanent possession.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Mahamanav Dr. Bhimrao Ramji Ambedkar|last=Gaikwad|first=Dr. Dnyanraj Kashinath|publisher=Riya Publication|year=2016|isbn=|location=|pages=187|language=Marathi}}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2012}} {{Pie chart |thumb = right |caption = Religious Affiliation in Luxembourg 2012{{cite web |url=http://ec.europa.eu/public_opinion/archives/ebs/ebs_393_en.pdf |title= Discrimination in the EU in 2012 – Special Eurobarometer 393 (The question asked was "Do you consider yourself to be...?") |publisher=European Commission |accessdate=2 February 2016}} |label1 = [[Catholic Church|Catholic]] |value1 = 67 |color1 = #2243B6 |label2 = [[Irreligion|Non-religious]]/[[Agnosticism|Agnostic]] |value2 = 14 |color2 = Honeydew |label3 = [[Atheism|Atheist]] |value3 = 6 |color3 = Black |label4 = [[Protestant]] |value4 = 3 |color4 = DodgerBlue |label5 = Other [[Christian]] |value5 = 3 |color5 = Turquoise |label6 = [[Islam|Muslim]] |value6 = 3 |color6 = Green |label7 = [[Buddhism|Buddhist]] |value7 = 1 |color7 = Yellow |label8 = [[Eastern Orthodox Church|Orthodox Christian]] |value8 = 1 |color8 = Orchid |label9 = Other [[religion]] |value9 = 1 |color9 = Chartreuse |label10 = Unknown |value10 = 1 |color10 = Silver }} [[Image:Luxembourg, Clervaux, Church.JPG|thumb|Church in [[Clervaux]], Luxembourg]] There are many active '''religions in [[Luxembourg]]'''. As of 2008, 72.4% of Luxembourg's population adhere to forms of [[Christianity]] (68.7% are [[Catholics]], 1.8% are [[Protestants]], while 1.9% adhere to other Christian denominations, especially [[Orthodox Christianity]]). 2.6% of the population follow non-Christian religions. 25% of the population do not have a religion.[http://www.luxembourg.public.lu/fr/actualites/2011/03/07-religion/ EVS Luxembourg 2008 CEPS/INSTEAD] ==Demographics== Since 1979 it has been illegal for the government to collect statistics on religious beliefs or practices.{{cite web |url=http://www.legilux.public.lu/leg/a/archives/1979/0291104/0291104.pdf#page=2 |title=Mémorial A, 1979, No. 29 |accessdate=1 August 2006 |format=PDF |publisher=Service central de législation|language=fr}} According to a 2010 [[Pew Research Center]] study 70.4% are Christian, 2.3% Muslim, 26.8% Unaffiliated and 0,5% other religions.[http://features.pewforum.org/grl/population-percentage.php Global Religious Landscape] Pew Research Center 2010 According to the most recent [[Eurobarometer|Eurobarometer Poll]] 2005,{{cite web|url=http://ec.europa.eu/public_opinion/archives/ebs/ebs_225_report_en.pdf |title=Eurobarometer on Social Values, Science and technology 2005 – page 11 |accessdate=5 May 2007}} * '''44%''' of Luxembourgish citizens responded that ''"they believe there is a God"''. * '''28%''' answered that ''"they believe there is some sort of spirit or life force"''. * '''22%''' answered that ''"they do not believe there is any sort of spirit, God, or life force"''. ==State intervention== Luxembourg is a secular state, but the Grand Duchy recognises and supports several denominations, in exchange for which, the state is allowed a hand in their affairs. This status, first afforded to the Catholic Church, stems from [[Napoleon I of France|Napoleon]]'s [[Concordat of 1801]], the principles of which have continued to apply to Luxembourg, despite its separation from France in 1815 and its subsequent [[United Kingdom of the Netherlands|Dutch]] ownership. Despite having the same roots as France's official position of ''[[laïcité]]'', Luxembourg's approach to religion has taken a different direction in the past 200 years, reducing the [[separation of church and state]], not increasing it. The state currently recognises the Catholic Church, Judaism, [[Greek Orthodox Church|Greek]] and [[Russian Orthodox Church|Russian]] [[Eastern Orthodox Church|Orthodox Christianity]], and Protestantism as officially mandated religions. In 2003, representatives of Islam, [[Anglicanism]], and [[Romanian Orthodox Church|Romanian]] and [[Serbian Orthodox Church|Serbian]] Orthodox Christianity engaged in discussions to be conferred similar status.[https://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2005/51566.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2004 – Luxembourg]. 8 November 2004. US Department of State. ''URL accessed 24 May 2006''. A process began in the mid-2000s in which increasingly the tight entanglement between church and state in Luxembourg was questioned. This was partially stimulated by several events, such as the debate on [[Catholic Church sexual abuse cases|Catholic Church sexual abuse]] or the Grandduke's religiously motivated refusal to sign a [[euthanasia]] bill adopted by Parliament.{{Cite news |url=http://hpd.de/node/6023 |title=Luxemburg: Sterbehilfe depenalisiert |author=Manuel Huss |work= |publisher=Humanistischer Pressedienst |date=18 December 2008 |accessdate=15 November 2015 |language=de}} This led to the 2007 formation of an alliance of eight organisations, who made the [[separation of church and state]] their goal.{{Cite news |url=http://hpd.de/node/3099 |title=Trennung von Kirche und Staat in Luxemburg |author=Grete Meißel |publisher=Humanistischer Pressedienst |date=31 October 2007 |accessdate=24 June 2013 |language=de}} In 2010, a petition was launched under the name of ''Trennung.lu'' ("Separation.lu"), that demanded the separation of church and state in Luxembourg. It was supported by, amongst others, the youth wings of several political parties.{{cite web |url=http://trennung.wollt.net/ |title=Trennung.lu |accessdate=2015-11-24 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100701095132/http://trennung.wollt.net/ |archivedate=1 July 2010 |df=dmy-all }} The [[Allianz vun Humanisten, Atheisten an Agnostiker]], founded in 2010, became one of the most vocal advocates of secularism in Luxembourg. In January 2015, the government concluded a new convention with the recognised religions, regrouping the Greek, Romanian, Serbian and Russian Orthodox Churches in one Orthodox Church in Luxembourg, represented by the Metropolitan Archbishop of Belgium, Exarch of the Low Countries and Luxembourg, under the jurisdiction of the [[Ecumenical Patriarchate of Constantinople]], and adding the Anglican Church and the Muslim Community of the Grand-Duchy of Luxembourg to the list of recognised religions.[https://www.gouvernement.lu/4369567/Convention.pdf Convention entre l’État du Grand-Duché de Luxembourg et les communautés religieuses établies au Luxembourg] This convention has not yet entered into force, however.[http://www.gouvernement.lu/4369493/20-cdp-accord Accord du gouvernement avec les communautés religieuses établies au Luxembourg - Article on gouvernment.lu] Moreover, seven non-religious organisations demanded a say in the negotiations about the future financing of religions by the state and the continuation of religion classes in public schools, both of which they demanded to be abolished.{{Cite news |url=http://www.lessentiel.lu/fr/news/dossier/cultes/story/Les-non-religieux-veulent-aussi-etre-consultes-26709291 |title=Les non-religieux veulent aussi être consultés |work=[[L'essentiel (newspaper)|L'essentiel]] |publisher=Edita SA |date=18 January 2015 |accessdate=21 November 2015 |language=fr}} == Catholic Church== {{Main article|Catholic Church in Luxembourg}} Catholicism is the most practised religion in Luxembourg. Luxembourg was a major centre for Christianity during the [[Middle Ages]], Catholicism was sustained through the [[Protestant Reformation|Reformation]] by the hierarchy, buildings, and traditions established in the preceding centuries. The Catholic Church has received state support since 1801. ==Protestantism== {{Main article|Protestantism in Luxembourg}} [[Protestantism]] was outlawed in Luxembourg until 1768. By 1815, Luxembourg had small populations of [[Lutherans]], [[Calvinists]], and [[Waldensians]]. In 1885, there were 1,100 recorded Protestants out of 213,000 inhabitants of Luxembourg, that is 0.516%. By 1914, there were more than 6,000, or approximately 2.3%. Today it's 3%. Protestantism is a [[minority religion]] in Luxembourg. They are divided across several Protestant churches and creeds, including [[Lutheranism]], [[Calvinism]], [[Anglicanism]], and diverse [[Evangelical Protestant]] churches. The largest Protestant churches in the Grand Duchy are the [[Protestant Church of Luxembourg]] (''PKL''), [[Protestant Reformed Church of Luxembourg]] (''PRKL''), [[Evangelical Church in Germany]], [[Church of England]], and [[Protestant Church in the Netherlands]]. The state has supported the PKL since 1894 and the PRKL since 1982. ==Islam== {{Main article|Islam in Luxembourg}} In Luxembourg there is about 10,000 to 12,000 Muslims (est. 2009), who represent 2.2% of the total population. In addition, hundreds of Muslims come to work in Luxembourg every workday. According to a 2009 [[Pew Research Center]] report, approximately 13,000 Muslims in Luxembourg.http://pewforum.org/uploadedfiles/Topics/Demographics/Muslimpopulation.pdf There are six mosques in Luxembourg as well as one multi-use room for Muslims, none of which have [[minaret]]s. Many Luxembourgian Muslims pray in mosques in France, Belgium or Germany. Most Muslims have origins in the [[Balkans]] ([[Bosniaks]] and [[Albanians]] approximately 60%), while Arab and other Muslim countries represent about 20%. Sub-Saharan Muslims account for about 5%, and 15% are other Europeans. ==Judaism== {{Main article|History of the Jews in Luxembourg}} Luxembourg's [[Jewish people|Jewish]] community dates back at least as far as the 13th century, making Judaism the minority religion that has been practised the longest in Luxembourg. Today, Luxembourg's Jews number approximately 1,200, of whom, 650 practise actively. There are very few [[Orthodox Judaism|Orthodox Jews]] in Luxembourg.[http://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/anti-semitism/report_lux.html Manifestations of Anti-Semitism in the European Union – Luxembourg]. 1 December 2003. European Union. ''URL accessed 24 May 2006''. During the [[Holocaust]], 1,945 Jewish Luxembourgers were killed, out of a pre-war population of 3,500. Judaism is supported by the state. == Irreligion == {{See also|Allianz vun Humanisten, Atheisten an Agnostiker}} [[File:AHA campagne stei dozou 2011.jpg|thumb|[[Allianz vun Humanisten, Atheisten an Agnostiker|AHA]]'s [[Atheist Bus Campaign]], spring 2011:
"Not religious? Stand up for it!"]] In the 2000s, surveys showed an increasing share of the population no longer feels connected to Catholicism. In 2002, 94% was still formally Catholic,Encarta-encyclopedie Winkler Prins (1993-2002) s.v. ''Luxemburg: feiten en cijfers''. Microsoft Corporation/Het Spectrum (in Dutch). but in 2008, 25% of the Luxembourgers said they did not belong to any religion. A lot of people were increasingly estranged by the Church's belief system, and yet were still members of it, solidifying the current situation. This caused both the association ''Liberté de conscience'' ("Freedom of Conscience") and the Internet portal ''sokrates.lu'' to launch the website ''Fraiheet.lu'' ("Freedom.lu") in 2009, to inform citizens about the options for [[religious disaffiliation]]. This secularisation, combined with the struggle to separate church and state, eventually led to the foundation of the [[Allianz vun Humanisten, Atheisten an Agnostiker]] in the spring of 2010. It intended to unite the hitherto scattered organised activities by humanist, atheist, agnostic, skeptical and secularist thinking people into one force.{{Cite news |url=http://hpd.de/node/10619 |title=AHA! Auftakt der Humanisten in Luxemburg |author=Fiona Lorenz |publisher=Humanistischer Pressedienst |date=11 November 2010 |accessdate=21 November 2015 |language=de}} The foundation was also explicitly welcomed by, amongst others, politicians from several parties.{{Cite web |url=http://iheu.org/luxembourg-launches-humanist-association/ |title=Luxembourg launches Humanist association |work=IHEU website |publisher=[[International Humanist and Ethical Union]] |date=3 November 2010 |accessdate=21 November 2015}} ==See also== *[[Religion in Belgium]] *[[Religion in the Netherlands]] ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} {{Luxembourg topics}} {{Religion in Europe}} [[Category:Religion in Luxembourg| ]] [[Category:Luxembourgian culture]] [[Category:Luxembourgian society]]

[[File:Chinguetti-biblio.jpg|thumb|[[Qur'an]] collection in a library in [[Chinguetti]]]] The people of '''Mauritania''' are nearly all adherents of [[Sunni Islam]] of [[Maliki]] school of [[jurisprudence]], influenced with [[Sufism]]. [[Mauritania]] is a country in Africa, bordering [[Algeria]], [[Mali]], [[Senegal]], and the [[Western Sahara]] (currently controlled by [[Morocco]]).<ref name="Leonard2006">{{cite book|author=Thomas M. Leonard|title=Encyclopedia of the Developing World|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3mE04D9PMpAC&pg=PA1004|accessdate=1 August 2012|year=2006|publisher=Taylor & Francis|isbn=978-0-415-97662-6|pages=1003–1004}}</ref> Officially, 100% of the country's citizens are Muslim,<ref name="CIA">{{cite web|title=Mauritania|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/mr.html|publisher=CIA World Factbook|accessdate=1 August 2012}}</ref> although there is a small community of [[Christian]]s, mainly of foreign nationality.<ref name="Group2004">{{cite book|author=Taylor & Francis Group|title=Europa World Year Book 2|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gP_-8rXzQs8C&pg=PA2851|accessdate=1 August 2012|date=September 2004|publisher=Taylor & Francis|isbn=978-1-85743-255-8|pages=2851}}</ref> The two largest [[Sufi Muslim]] [[tariqa]]s in Mauritania are [[Tijaniyyah]] and [[Qadiriyya]].<ref name="Esposito2004"/> Because of the ethnic and tribal divisions in the country, religion is seen by the government as essential for national unity.<ref name="Annual Report on International Religious Freedom, 2004"/>
There are around 4,500 [[Roman Catholics]] in the country of foreign origin.<ref name="Group2004"/> There are also a few adherents of [[Judaism]] working in the country.<ref name="Annual Report on International Religious Freedom, 2004"/>
==History== It was trade with Muslim merchants that brought Islam into the region, in the 8th century.<ref name="Esposito2004">{{cite book|author=John L. Esposito|title=The Oxford Dictionary of Islam|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6VeCWQfVNjkC&pg=PA196|accessdate=1 August 2012|date=21 October 2004|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-512559-7|page=196}}</ref>
The [[Almoravid dynasty]] rose to power in the western [[Maghreb]] during the 11th century, and prosletyzed Islam throughout the region.<ref name="Leonard2006"/> Members of the Gadala Berbers brought back the theologian [[Abdallah ibn Yasin]] from [[Mecca]] in 1035, where they traveled for the [[hajj]], to expunge the paganism still prevalent in Mauritania.<ref name="Pazzanita2008"/> Although Islam had existed in the region prior to the Almoravids, Almoravid rule accelerated the spread of Islam and removed [[animist]] influences on local Islamic practices.<ref name="cs">{{cite web|title=A Country Study: Mauritania|url=http://lcweb2.loc.gov/frd/cs/mrtoc.html|work=Country Studies|publisher=Library of Congress|accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref> Ibn Yasin's strict interpretation of Islam alienated many of the Berbers, and the theologian was expelled. Undaunted, he accumulated a devoted following of loyal believers and an army, the foundation of the Almoravid dynasty. ibn Yasin's military expansion converted tribe members of the Gadala, Lemtuma, and Messufa Berbers of the region to Islam. The capture of [[Sijilmasa]] and [[Aoudaghost]], important cities in the [[Trans-Saharan trade]], allowed them to dominate the trade routes of the Sahara. The Almoravids converted the Berbers inhabiting modern-day Mauritania to the [[Maliki]] school of [[Sunni Islam]], which remains dominant in Mauritania to this day.<ref name="Pazzanita2008">{{cite book|last=Pazzanita|first=Anthony G. |title=Historical Dictionary of Mauritania|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-KU_9MfXKKYC&pg=PA60|accessdate=1 August 2012|year=2008|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield|isbn=978-0-8108-5596-0|pages=58–60|ref=harv}}</ref>
ibn Yasin was succeeded by [[Abu Bakr ibn Umar]], a chieftain of the Lamtuna Berbers. Fighting between the Lemtuma and Messufa led ibn Umar to declare a holy war against the [[Ghana Empire]] to unify the tribes against a common enemy. The war, which lasted for fourteen years, spread Islam to the members of the [[Soninke people]], founders of Ghana.<ref name="Pazzanita2008"/> The political influence of the Almoravids waned as the dynasty declined, but Islamic adherence was firmly cemented in the country.<ref name="cs"/>
The political influence of the [[Kunta (tribe)|Kunta tribe]] between the 16th and 18th centuries bolstered the popularity of [[Qadiriyya|Qadiri Sufism]] in the region.<ref name="Lapidus2002">{{cite book|author=Ira M. Lapidus|title=A History of Islamic Societies|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=I3mVUEzm8xMC&pg=PA416|accessdate=1 August 2012|date=22 August 2002|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-77933-3|pages=409–410}}</ref> Between the 16th and 18th centuries, declaration of [[jihad]]s by Muslim theologians pushed for the establishment of Islamic governance in West Africa. In the 17th century, Nasir al-Din led a jihad in Mauritania, drawing support from Berbers frustrated with the corruption of the region's Arab rulers.<ref name="cs"/>
The [[French colonial empire]] expanded into Mauritania by the 19th century.<ref name="cs"/> The West African jihads were brought to an end, following crackdowns by British and French colonists.<ref name="Lapidus2002"/> In an effort to thwart militarism and threats of rebellion, French colonial administrators encouraged the influence of zaqiya, the religious tribes of Mauritania, over hassan, Mauritania's warrior tribes.{{sfn|Pazzanita|2008| pp=277-278}}
===Post-independence === The country declared its independence in 1960 and established itself as an [[Islamic Republic]].<ref name="Pazzanita2008"/> Independence brought [[Moktar Ould Daddah]] into power, who promoted Islam during his rule. A military coup d'état ousted Daddah in 1978.<ref name="ce">{{cite web|last=Thurston|first=Alex|title=Mauritania's Islamists|url=http://carnegieendowment.org/2012/03/01/mauritania-s-islamists#|work=Carnegie Paper|publisher=Carnegie Endowment|accessdate=8 August 2012}}</ref> Colonel [[Mohamed Khouna Ould Haidalla]], one of the participants of the coup, became head of the government in 1980, and implemented [[Sharia]] law. [[Maaouya Ould Sid'Ahmed Taya]], successor of Ould Haidalla, reversed some of these changes, but was ousted in a military coup in 2005.<ref name="ce"/>
Political Islam, or [[Islamism]], was introduced in the region during the 1970s. The instability that followed the coup that deposed Daddah invited elements of the [[Muslim Brotherhood]], [[Wahabbism]], and [[Tablighi Jamaat]]. The Islamists united as a political party in the 1980s, but were politically repressed starting in 1994.<ref name="SoaresOtayek2007">{{cite book|author1=Benjamin F. Soares|author2=René Otayek|title=Islam and Muslim Politics in Africa|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hMpf-gyCrRAC&pg=PA29|accessdate=1 August 2012|date=15 September 2007|publisher=Macmillan|isbn=978-1-4039-7964-3|pages=28–34}}</ref> Government pressure on Islamist organizations continued throughout the 2000s. Funding by [[Saudi Arabia]] and other Gulf monarchies supported the establishment of Islamic schools, centers, and charities around the country, but were largely shut down by the government in 2003. In 2005, Islamists were arrested and accused of terrorism. Of the original eighty arrested, eighteen remained in prison by 2006.<ref name="us">{{cite web|title=Mauritania|url=https://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/irf/2006/71313.htm|work=International Religious Freedom Report 2006|publisher=U.S. Department of State|accessdate=8 August 2012}}</ref>
===Islam=== [[File:Chinguetti-biblio.jpg|thumb|150px|[[Qur'an]] collection in a library in [[Chinguetti]]]] Islam is by far the largest and most influential religion in the country, and has been since the 10th century.<ref name="Pazzanita2008"/> According to government census, 100% of the country's citizens are Muslim.<ref name="CIA"/> Like much of North Africa, Mauritanians follow the Maliki school of Islam.<ref name="Pazzanita2008"/>
Islam is the [[state religion]], and [[sharia]] is used as the basis of judicial decisions.<ref name="Annual Report on International Religious Freedom, 2004"/> The five member High Council of Islam determines the compatibility of secular laws with Islamic laws.<ref name="Group2004"/>
==Government restrictions on religion== In Mauritania, religious and secular NGOs are granted [[tax exemption]].<ref name="Annual Report on International Religious Freedom, 2004">{{cite book|title=Annual Report on International Religious Freedom, 2004|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=04dlwzB2SvcC&pg=PA75|accessdate=1 August 2012|date=4 August 2005|publisher=Government Printing Office|isbn=978-0-16-072552-4|pages=75–77}}</ref> Based on the [[Apostasy in Islam|sharia stance on apostasy]], the government forbids converting Muslims to competing religions. The publication of religious materials that are not Islamic is restricted. Religious education is considered mandatory, but only makes up a small portion of the public school curriculum.<ref name="Annual Report on International Religious Freedom, 2004"/>
According to the [[Pew Research Center]], although social conflict caused by religious hostilities is ranked Low in Mauritania, the amount of government restriction on the practice of religion is ranked High. Mauritania is the twelfth most religiously restrictive country in the world, ranked between [[Indonesia]] and [[Pakistan]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Global Restrictions on Religion |url=http://www.pewforum.org/newassets/images/reports/restrictions/restrictionsfullreport.pdf |publisher=Pew Research Center |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130117012234/http://www.pewforum.org/newassets/images/reports/restrictions/restrictionsfullreport.pdf |archivedate=January 17, 2013 }}</ref>

Karthala, Paris, 2005, {{p.|45-55}} {{ISBN|2-8458-6583-X}} * Sakho Mamadou Dickall, ''La littérature religieuse mauritanienne'', s. l., 1986, 127 p. * [[Paul Marty]], ''Études sur l'Islam maure'', E. Leroux, Paris, 1916, 252 p.

For the philosopher Shankara, see '''[[Adi Shankara]]'''}} {{More citations needed|date=January 2011}} {{Infobox Hindu leader |image = Raja Ravi Varma - Sankaracharya.jpg |alt = Adi shankara |caption = '''Jagadguru Adi Shankaracharya with his four disciples - Padmapadacharya, Sureshwaracharya, Hastamalakacharya & Totakacharya'''}} The four main Shankaracharya Mathas/Peethas are listed in the following table.
